newsitem.title: UK: S&P keeps San Diego County sec ratings on Watch.
newsitem.headline: S&P keeps San Diego County sec ratings on Watch.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said on Tuesday it maintained San Diego County, California's general fund-supported securities on CreditWatch with negative implications where they were placed on September 27, 1995.

S&P said the continued lack of a workable plan for meeting the county's solid waste needs, including one that achieves competitive tipping fees and meets the system's near-term capital needs, would place additional pressures on the county's general fund and likely would result in a lowering of the outstanding ratings.

In July, the county successfully defeased its $134.2 million California Pollution Control Financing Authority solid waste revenue bonds, issued in 1991 to finance the North County Recycling Center, by pulling together a variety of sources, of which over $95 million were directly or indirectly derived from the general fund.

The defeasance allowed the county to lower operational costs so that tipping fees could be reduced to a more competitive $40 per ton. Without a competitive fee, the solid-waste system faced the loss of additional waste flow and eventual financial insolvency.
The system, however, continues to operate with narrow margins and has many pressing capital needs that must be incorporated into a longer-term plan.
